bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, August 25, 1925

div1.p: Carter explains that her father's health is not good, but that he was able to put in a full month of work in July so that his History of Yellow Fever will be ready for a final revision.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, August 25, 1925
div1.opener:
Taxi to Ly. C
and return.
Book-
Expenses.
/LC
2.35--
i.e. 1.15 each way.
2122 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
August 25, 1925.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
Father has had two very bad days and nights--still disoriented
from the chloral, though he roused up day before yesterday afternoon
and spoke of the book and the elimination of yellow fever for about
ten minutes. The sciatica seems to be getting worse again, so I judge
we will have to try another injection of novocaine. But for this most
unfortunate complication I believe we could have been back at work by
now as his speech has cleared up considerably.

As I do not know when, or if, he can do any more work person-
ally on the History of Yellow Fever (though, as I wrote you previously,
I have practically all his notes and inserts for its final revision up to date) I
feel that you would not wish me to wait as I have done heretofore before
notifying you as to the time spent on it since my last letter on the
subject. Since so doing, Father has put in exactly one month's work
on the book, from July 1st. to July 31st.--at 6 P. M. Lord! I'm glad
I didn't stop him from working overtime that last day!

I am also enclosing itemized account of expenses incurred in
writing the History of Yellow Fever since July 1st.

With very best remembrances to yourself, and please thank Drs.
Drs.
-2-
Vincent and Rose for their cables when you write them and Dr. Heiser
for his letter as I have practically no time for writing. Also, thank
you once more for telling them of Father's illness.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours. 1 inclosure.
Dr. F. F. Russell, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York City, N. Y.
